The abuse of Iraqi prisoners 
      at Abu Ghraib, a story broken on 60 Minutes II a few 
      years ago, raised questions about the interrogation and treatment of 
      detainees in Iraq and 
      stained the image of the U.S. around the world. In 
      our first story, you will see how it has also changed the life of the man 
      who brought those infamous pictures to the authorities. CNN's 
      Anderson Cooper interviews Joe Darby, the former military policeman 
      who turned those pictures in, but who is paying a high price for it. No 
      longer able to return to his hometown because of threats – some of the 
      soldiers he turned in lived there, too – he now lives with his wife at an 
      undisclosed location. "I worry about the one guy who wants to get 
      even with me, and that one guy could hurt me and my family," says Darby, 
      who would do it again because, he tells Cooper, the abusers committed a 
      crime. (OAD: Dec. 10, 
      2006)
 
Watch an 
      excerpt.

 
We'll also look this week at a 
      new kind of American family. They're half-siblings conceived by the same 
      anonymous sperm donor, and they are connecting with each other on the 
      Internet. Correspondent Steve 
      Kroft meets two families that discovered they used sperm 
      from the same donor. They've begun to raise their respective children as 
      siblings.Their mothers talk frequently on the phone and they get together 
      every few weeks. One of the mothers, Robin Anderson, tells Kroft about the 
      children, "They don't have the donor, the father; they have each other... 
      We're a great family match." Steve's story takes a surprising turn when he 
      sets out to find the donor. (OAD: March 19, 
      2006)
 
Watch
Kroft's 
      reporter's notebook.

 
Our third story involves those 
      bound by an experience that killed millions: Holocaust survivors.  Correspondent Scott Pelley talks 
      to three concentration camp survivors who touch and read their own 
      documents for the first time at the secret archive containing the records 
      of 17.5 million victims of Hitler's Reich. Kept in the German city of 
      Bad 
      Arolsen on 16 miles of shelving, the archive not 
      only serves as a powerful reminder of the horror we can never forget, it 
      offers a challenge to the naysayer. "Those people who said the Holocaust 
      didn’t happen, like the president of Iran, if they have any questions 
      about it, please come to Bad Arolsen and check it out for themselves," 
      says one of the survivors, Miki Schwartz. (OAD: Dec. 17, 
      2006)
